instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER: What is SMC_ADAPTER? SMC_ADAPTER_EN is an abbreviation of SMC_ADAPTER_EN, which enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a (2011 MacBook Pro 15) that was running a memtest86 when it spontaneously shutdown. It will not start up again. The power connector stays green, even though the battery is at ~10% charge. 
SMC reset does not work. 
SMC bypass does not work.
Left battery disconnected overnight, then plugged in power cable: no fan spin.
Plugged in after disconnected all peripherals from logic board except fans: no fan spin.
No water damage.
Logic board was replaced by Apple maybe... 4 years back? For GPU failure.

Probed the following:
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 16.7V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.48V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - [B]pulsing[/B] 0-5V ~2Hz
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> - [B]pulsing[/B] 0-5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - [B]pulsing[/B] 0-3.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_ENET</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_AVCC</SIGNAL> - 3.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_EN</SIGNAL> - [B]pulsing[/B] 0-3.5V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - [B]pulsing[/B] 0-3.5V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - [B]pulsing[/B] 0-3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER</SIGNAL> - [B]pulsing[/B] 0 - 3.46V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>G3_POWERON_L</SIGNAL> - 0V

My best guess is SMC or <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>? Any ideas if I am on the right track / have the right issue nailed down? I don't want to blindly jump into replacing the SMC if I don't have to... it looks like a pain.

Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Be sure to use original 85W charger.
Battery should charge even in off state.
If Magsafe stuck in green light, there may be a problem with SMC, or battery.

Check diode mode to ground on all big coils; starting with L7220/60.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Thanks!

I am using the original charger that came with the laptop (its a new one that apple replaced cause my old one frayed).

The battery was replaced at the same time as the motherboard so it is relatively new; also I don't have that many cycles on it (maybe 100?) It does not charge at all. I left it plugged in for about 2 hours and the MagSafe stayed green the whole time and the battery indicator light did not change.

I will check the coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Please write directly on the Reply Box.
I don't see a real reason to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Please, maintain forum aesthetic.

Check voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.
Disconnect BIL and see if starts charging.

threads.message:

Battery

SDA - 0.522V (diode) 4.473V (volt)

Disconnecting battery indicator light seems to have no effect, still not charging (MagSafe stays green).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
"L7220 - 0.001 V"
There is a short circuit.
Left the coil one side and check where the short remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Not sure what you mean by left the coil one side.

edit: do you mean desolder one side?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Sorry for misstyping; yes, I meant LIFT...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Removed the coil. Diode readings:
Pad 1 - 0.001V
Pad 2 - 0.483V

Removed caps 7252 and 7250. Both 0.001V diode readings.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Pure short to ground on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> power rail.
Voltage injection method will help you to find the culprit.
Read more on the forum, before applying voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Tracked down the short to <CAPACITOR>C4690</CAPACITOR>. Replaced cap and no more evaporating alcohol / current draw. However, there is still no fan spin. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> still pulses up and down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is stable now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Negative. <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> still pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Did you try again SMC bypass?
Turns on with both charger and battery connected?
Is the battery charging now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
No change with SMC bypass. Still does not turn on.

Battery does not charge

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Check for pulse at all big coils; triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.message:
L3895 - 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Did you check the coils at same time when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: I am not sure what you mean by "trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>". The <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is at 3.48V the whole time the MagSafe is plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Read "HOW TO collection" thread please...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: The pulsing inductors measured above continue pulsing when I ground the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>. However, the pulsing frequency approximately doubles while <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> is grounded, and afterwards when I disconnect the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>, it goes back to its previous frequency.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Don't ground <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, trigger it; like when pressing power button, less than 1s.
Use <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR>/16 pads, instead of power button; when work with the board alone on the desk.
You must check signals and voltages reaction at the same moment.

In fact, solder an wire on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and touch any metal plate, simulating power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Understood. Please see the attached images for what I mean by grounding. The blue line is the scope of the "trigger". The pulsing is still there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: When using o-scope, check for DC pulse at output pin of the coil; where the filter cap is connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: The plots were taken with probe on pin 2 of inductors L7260 and L7770.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Very strange pulses.
If you hold down (to ground) <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> for 5s, still get pulse on these coils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: yep still pulses, as shown in attached images

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Keep <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> down more time, it should turn off the board.
Only <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> must remain present after and no pulse on other coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
I do love the way that you say 'Read HOW TO collection'

Do you know that new members such as me have no idea where that section is,. Cannot see it, cannot search for ''how to' as that brings up an error. 

Hiw about you simply paste in the link to help new mebers?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Not sure what happened but the behavior changed. So this is the process:

Power cycle
<SIGNAL>L7260_1_1</SIGNAL>
Disconnect <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>L7260_1_2</SIGNAL>
Power cycle
<SIGNAL>L7260_2</SIGNAL>

So it looks like the behavior changed after the first long press of <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. Now it seems like grounding <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> causes the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> to go to 2.5V as opposed to pulsing. Then after grounding is removed, the voltage stays constant at 0.5V. The pulsing does not return until the board is power cycled again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Not sure what happened but the behavior changed. So this is the process:

Power cycle
<SIGNAL>L7260_1_1</SIGNAL>
Disconnect <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>L7260_1_2</SIGNAL>
Power cycle
<SIGNAL>L7260_2</SIGNAL>

So it looks like the behavior changed after the first long press of <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. Now it seems like grounding <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> causes the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> to go to 2.5V as opposed to pulsing. Then after grounding is removed, the voltage stays constant at 0.5V. The pulsing does not return until the board is power cycled again.

After power cycling, the pulsing starts again. During that time, the other coils that show pulsing (L7770 for example) continue to pulse. However, after the pulsing stops (after holding <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> for more than 1 second, as stated above), those lines go to 0V.

Also, not shown here, after power cycle, and while it is pulsing, when I do a short "press" of <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, grounding for maybe 1 second? the voltage jumps to ~2.4, and then when ungrounded it stays at 0.5V. However, if I just "tap" <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, grounding maybe 0.1seconds?, the voltage jumps to ~2.4, but when ungrounded goes back to pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Once Magsafe is connected, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> must get stable (<CAPACITOR>C7290</CAPACITOR>), no matters board is on or off.
Confirm your actual case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: it is stable at 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: voltage pulses at <CAPACITOR>C7290</CAPACITOR>, same as L7260, once MagSafe is connected. once <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is grounded for 1-2 seconds and then ungrounded, it stays stable at 0.75V, the same as L7260 from above.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
I think in early post you've said to have steady <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> voltage.
Check now <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, SMC <SIGNAL>RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> -12.48V
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.48V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.48

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>:
[LIST]
[*]after MagSafe connection: pulsing 0 - 3.5V
[*]after holding <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> for 3s: stable at 3.5V
[/LIST]
All behavior above, with the exception of <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> after holding <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, is the exact same as it was initially.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> has never been stable at 3.3V. Once MagSafe is connected it pulses from 0 - 3.5V. The only time it is stable is after the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> long hold to ground, after which it settles at 0.75V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
You cannot get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> untill <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is stable.
Remove <RESISTOR>R7940</RESISTOR> and run a wire from <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> to <CAPACITOR>C7942</CAPACITOR>.
Check if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> gets steady voltage then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
removed <RESISTOR>R7940</RESISTOR>, soldered a wire from pin 2 of where <RESISTOR>R7940</RESISTOR> used to be (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_EN</SIGNAL>) and also happens to be pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7942</CAPACITOR>, to pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>).

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C9487</CAPACITOR> pulsing 0 - 3.5V as usual.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Post basic voltages of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> now; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Pulsing behavior on some pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
I asked about DC voltages!
PLEASE, hide the o-scope somewhere...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
The voltage is on the left axis of each image.
Pin 12 - Pulse 0-3.5V
Pin 13 - Pulse 0-2V
Pin 21 - 3.5V
Pin 22 - 3.35V
Pin 23 - 12.25 - 12.75V ... weird interference, matches pulse frequency
Pin 29 - Pulse 0.9 - 5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
I understand <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is still pulsing.
There should be a problem with SMC, or some of its sensors.

Check exact ohm resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Remove F7040/41 and check the voltage at <CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Pin 17/18 - 3 ohm
Pin 27/28 - 20 ohm
<CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR> 12.58V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
So <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> only fluctuates when F7040/41 are soldered in place?
Looks like SMC issue...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Wait hold on I feel like im missing something here. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> never fluctuated at any point. Even in the beginning before removing any components, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was stable at 12.5V (post #1).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
"Pin 23 - 12.25 - 12.75V ... weird interference, matches pulse frequency"
Dropping to 12.25V is sign of non working SMC, or communication problem between SMC and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Please clarify actual situation.
Only DC readings, forget the o-scope.
Trying to write down too much information, is not always helpful.
Sometime make us to lose the focus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Ok so with the multimeter, which doesn't really update very quickly, it looks around 12.6V on Pin23, though the number moves around a little bit. This is similar to the DC voltage randomly jumping from 0V -> 2.3V -> 0.7V -> 0.2V -> etc etc for pulsing pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Fluctuating like 12.4-12.7V will not be a big problem.
But dropping to 12.25V is very bad.
However, you didn't mention such fluctuation at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Got it. So since it is in the 12.4 - 12.7V range, what is the next step?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Get steady <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: So based on what you said earlier about the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and SMC, are you suggesting the next thing to do is to replace both components or something? The last concrete step was to remove the fuses.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Check if is possible to cut off trace for pin 12/<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>.
Then check if <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> gets steady high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: It seems like the trace goes under the chip. There is no trace leading out from pin 12 of the <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
In an earlier post, you've said to get steady 3V at <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, if press <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> for 3s.
Is that still true?
If yes, check if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> gets steady at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
I am super confused what is going on now because the pulsing frequency has now changed to what looks like 0.2Hz.

So what you stated is true, if I press <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> for about 1s (3s would be the same), <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> gets solid 3.5V. <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> gets solid 2.1V. <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> doesn't look right only having 2.1V...

I have attached 3 images. <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is the blue line in the images, while the yellow is the tested pin.

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.png - data capture after a power cycle, and then pressing the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.png - after a power cycle, and then pressing the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
3V3_S5_POWERCYCLE.png - <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> immediately after MagSafe power cycle, no <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> triggering
SMC_PM_G2_EN_POWERCYCLE.png - <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> immediately after MagSafe power cycle, no <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> triggering

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Please, let o-scope aside; do not complicate the job more than needed.

Post <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> voltages, when you get steady <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.
If you don't get correct <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> in that case, there's something wrong in <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> area.
Inspect all surrounding resistors and traces; pay atention to <RESISTOR>R7260</RESISTOR>/61, <RESISTOR>R7263</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7264</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Note for all "cycling" pins the numbers are all approximate (value changes quickly so its whatever I could see at max).

12 - 3.48V
13 - .158V
21 - 3.48V
22 - 1.8 down to 1.7V then cycles 0.25Hz
23 - 1.9 down to 1.7V cycles 0.25Hz
29 - 1V cycles down to 0.8V 0.25Hz

<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_VFBR_R</SIGNAL> - spikes to 2V drops to 0V 0.25Hz
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_VFBR</SIGNAL> - spikes 0.6V "  "
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_DRVH</SIGNAL> - spikes 1.6V "  "
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_TG</SIGNAL> - spikes 2V "  "

I don't see anything obviously wrong with components in this area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
Remove <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR>.
Check if symptom changes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
12, 13, 21 same as before

22 - 0V
23 - 1.51V solid
29 - 1.7V solid

<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_VFB2_R</SIGNAL> - 1.9V solid
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_VFB2</SIGNAL> - 0.58V solid
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_DRVH</SIGNAL> - 1.9V solid
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_TG</SIGNAL> - 1.9V solid

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Did you ever get steady <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Yes. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is steady at 3.48V as measured from pin 12 of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. Just to note, before and after <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> removal, pin 12 was at 3.48V solid.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Then <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is not stable at 12.5V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message: Nope it is solid right now at 1.5V. It did used to be around 12.5V with some fluctuations but since then we have removed a few components so not sure if that should be expected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
OK, we start from scratch then.
Remove F7040/1 and check if get stable <CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR> voltage.

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> should stay at 3V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
F7040/1 were removed since post #40.

<CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR> is solid 12.58V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> solid 3.48V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
"F7040/1 were removed since post #40."
Wait, you say that we lost so many days without <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on the board???

I asked you to do that for test purpose only.
I never could imagine you didn't solder back the fuses...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
So the changes I have noted so far are:

Post 34 - Remove <RESISTOR>R7940</RESISTOR> and run a wire from <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> to <CAPACITOR>C7942</CAPACITOR>
Post 40 - Remove F7040/41
Post 56 - Remove <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR>

So what you are saying is undo all previous changes, except removing the fuses per post 64? None of the component removals / jumpering were reversed up to this point.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Spontaneous Shutdown, No Startup
threads.message:
We really have to start from zero...
Put back all components, in original configuration.
Then post again voltages and signals from power on sequence.

BTW, let the o-scope aside, we don't need it.
